snippet.textDisplay: We've been at peak smartphone for the last couple years. Anything that comes out now seems to be gimmicky because they are out of ideas and have nothing else to do. They are putting old technology that's we had in other devices maybe not phones, but the technology has been around for a while.  The only new thing is the foldable screen. That's it. And a slightly better cameras.  I'm sure s11 camera will be better than the s10 but I doubt even with its 100 megapixel camera it's going to be that's much better.
snippet.textOriginal: We've been at peak smartphone for the last couple years. Anything that comes out now seems to be gimmicky because they are out of ideas and have nothing else to do. They are putting old technology that's we had in other devices maybe not phones, but the technology has been around for a while.  The only new thing is the foldable screen. That's it. And a slightly better cameras.  I'm sure s11 camera will be better than the s10 but I doubt even with its 100 megapixel camera it's going to be that's much better.

snippet.textDisplay:
Peak? please... It's only at its peak if a smartphone to you is its sensors. Even though can handle upgrades.
The battery technology is ancient. Wait till we get a new tech like graphite or who knows what which not only it will last for weeks but it will charge in a couple of minutes and you won't lose energy in heat or the battery won't be under stress above 80% or below 30%.
Wait till the chips use smaller nanometer architecture.

Software: Should I include OS and native apps that both apple and google are behind?
I should be able in Google Fit to log any aspect of my health so I can be the holder of that info and not just in a folder of my Dr's office. I want to change Dr? Good, just NFC my phone somewhere he gets my health database so he can do his full job.
I want to be able to store my eyesight changes with graphs of how it changes overtime cause I already lost my glasses prescription papers they gave my 12 years ago.

So many software ideas...

snippet.textDisplay: don't forget. If you would try to leave with the same smartphone for more than 2 years, in the vast majority of time, you would run into serious problems like: no more updates (in case of android phones), batteries that won't hold more than 65% than it did when it was new, and problems with various apps that wouldn't let you use their features because you need to update them and the OS as well, but you can't do it because of the latter. So, the clear image is: you could leave with a smartphone for more than 2 years, but a lot of the new developed features for the new phones would not be accessible...kind of like living with a motorola flip-phone in the year 2020.
snippet.textOriginal: don't forget. If you would try to leave with the same smartphone for more than 2 years, in the vast majority of time, you would run into serious problems like: no more updates (in case of android phones), batteries that won't hold more than 65% than it did when it was new, and problems with various apps that wouldn't let you use their features because you need to update them and the OS as well, but you can't do it because of the latter. So, the clear image is: you could leave with a smartphone for more than 2 years, but a lot of the new developed features for the new phones would not be accessible...kind of like living with a motorola flip-phone in the year 2020.

snippet.textDisplay:
Is there a phone I can use to act as a recording device for my laptop?
I am carrying around a 1080p 60fps 90degree webcam and cheap condenser mic in my laptop bag as my edc.
I'd rather use the phone in my pocket as a cardiod polar pattern mic with a camera perspective that doesn't point up my nose while I'm recording.
OnePlus (my tool of choice) doesn't do this. At this point I'm not sure if this feature is actually a thing.
snippet.textOriginal:
Is there a phone I can use to act as a recording device for my laptop?

I'd rather use the phone in my pocket as a cardiod polar pattern mic with a camera perspective that doesn't point up my nose while I'm recording.
OnePlus (my tool of choice) doesn't do this. At this point I'm not sure if this feature is actually a thing.

snippet.textDisplay:
What if we think of development of any product as a series of trajectories?

The first was PDA's and early smartphones, the second was the iPhone and everything up to now, the third will be foldables and who knows what other innovations.

So we're at the peak of this development trajectory, the next one has just started.
snippet.textOriginal:
What if we think of development of any product as a series of trajectories?

The first was PDA's and early smartphones, the second was the iPhone and everything up to now, the third will be foldables and who knows what other innovations.

So we're at the peak of *this* development trajectory, the next one has just started.

snippet.textDisplay: We have not. And my reason for saying that is.. There still isn't a place online I can go to and pick out what I want in a smartphone and have them build that smartphone. For example.. Maybe I want a 5000mah battery with a 4k screen, headphone jack and ip68 rating. When I can go online, pick those specs and have my smartphone phone built, shipped and ready to be activated by the time I get it.. That's when I'll consider that we've hit the peak of smartphones. Im still upset we can't do that with vehicles yet. Maybe I don't want a new Ford mustang. Maybe I want a new 1965 ford mustang built in 2020.. I wish companies would do this lol

snippet.textDisplay:
Wait what? 'Almost never a good reason to spend $1000 on a smartphone"? Is there ever a good reason? There is never a good reason to spend that much on a phone. People are shopping for cameras that have access to social media for the most part.
.
I notice when you demo a phone, swiping left and right is effortless. I swear my Pixel 3XL doesn't even sense my thumb. Especially with IG. If I use pen with a rubber stylus tip, there is no problem. But when I use my thumb, I sometimes have keep trying multiple times.
.
As for the peak car debate, only the luxury models have the features you mention. When there is driver assist, blind spot warnings, active braking on everything from a Bentley to a Sentra as a standard feature, then you might be able to claim we may be at peak car. But then luxury cars will still have the best safety features. The sad part is a lot of those features are not on the cars most people can afford until production costs reach a point they can be added.
snippet.textOriginal:
Wait what? 'Almost never a good reason to spend $1000 on a smartphone"? Is there ever a good reason? There is never a good reason to spend that much on a phone. People are shopping for cameras that have access to social media for the most part.
.
I notice when you demo a phone, swiping left and right is effortless. I swear my Pixel 3XL doesn't even sense my thumb. Especially with IG. If I use pen with a rubber stylus tip, there is no problem. But when I use my thumb, I sometimes have keep trying multiple times.
.
As for the peak car debate, only the luxury models have the features you mention. When there is driver assist, blind spot warnings, active braking on everything from a Bentley to a Sentra as a standard feature, then you might be able to claim we may be at peak car. But then luxury cars will still have the best safety features. The sad part is a lot of those features are not on the cars most people can afford until production costs reach a point they can be added.

snippet.textDisplay: I think what determines peak for anything is the image of the future/goal of that thing. When iPhone 1 came out, there was a clear image for the future: no bezels, large battery, better camera, etc. With cars, some people would argue that peak car is a green car. Others might argue it is flying cars. But the point is that there tends to be an image, so not many people would say we've already reached peak car. But with phones, other than some type of hologram tech or something, there isn't a significantly different image. Sure we can improve on the battery and the cameras some more, but there really isn't any radical, new goal to work towards, so changes don't feel as impactful.
snippet.textOriginal: I think what determines peak for anything is the image of the future/goal of that thing. When iPhone 1 came out, there was a clear image for the future: no bezels, large battery, better camera, etc. With cars, some people would argue that peak car is a green car. Others might argue it is flying cars. But the point is that there tends to be an image, so not many people would say we've already reached peak car. But with phones, other than some type of hologram tech or something, there isn't a significantly different image. Sure we can improve on the battery and the cameras some more, but there really isn't any radical, new goal to work towards, so changes don't feel as impactful.

snippet.textDisplay: hmm, i think you need to define peak. improvements can always happen. I think peak is the point where everything is so good, that companies stop putting attention on being new and better and focus on making it cheap and usable. i think the midrange market is going to become the main market and the flagship becomes the niche is when we hit the peak. while we are treading, we havent hit that point yet as a mass of people are still going for the flagship.

snippet.textDisplay: I feel like a similar thing could be said about cameras. Camera YouTube makes me feel like my 2-year-old camera isnt going to cut it but at the end of the day I'm still rocking an amazing camera that can clearly be competitive against the new stuff. Maybe "peak camera" and "peak smartphone" are actually just us feeling FOMO. That curve made a lot of sense to me and I'm going to keep it in my back pocket when I feel like I'm not good enough!
snippet.textOriginal: I feel like a similar thing could be said about cameras. Camera YouTube makes me feel like my 2-year-old camera isnt going to cut it but at the end of the day I'm still rocking an amazing camera that can clearly be competitive against the new stuff. snippet.textDisplay:
The next big thing would be making the BATTERY LAST 7 DAYS! Even if the standby time is 7 days for starters would be good. For me, my iPhone 6 is still going strong in terms of the feature set. I don't think the newer phones do a lot more than what the iPhone 6 can. Edge to edge screens are a wasted effort, there is really no practical benefit. It rather makes holding the phone difficult with stray touches. It seems like they did it just for the heck of it and for the cool factor. And also to remain relevant against the competition.

Improving battery technology would benefit not only smartphones but also other things like electric cars and stuff that use fossil fuels.
snippet.textOriginal:

snippet.textDisplay: As a car guy... We are absolutely nowhere NEAR peak car. Electric is so so new in the grand scheme of things. Self driving, IoT integration, even normal petrol engines have so much more development that we haven't conquered like variable compression rate (go Nissan for the first concept of actually achieving it!!), Fully electronically actuated valve timing (gotta love Keoniggsegg), there's so so much more that we're still a long, long way from fully understanding
